Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: A large gathering has assembled for a special remembrance, and no one else present is authorized to lead.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a message from Amir: “Rough day. Can we talk?” My heart aches for him. As his girlfriend, I want to be there, to listen, to reassure him that he’s not alone. I imagine us sitting together, my hand in his, letting him vent about his boss and deadlines. But as I reach for my coat, my phone buzzes again—this time, it’s the mosque committee. The regular imam is ill, and tonight’s remembrance gathering is larger than usual. They need me to lead the prayers; no one else is authorized. I feel the weight of the community’s expectation pressing on my shoulders. My mind races: Amir needs me, but so does my congregation. I can’t be in two places at once. My heart pulls in one direction, my duty in another. I stand frozen in my hallway, torn between comforting the person I love and fulfilling my responsibility to my faith and community.
